pli-tv-kd2:12.5.4: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.5: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.6: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should abolish this may-stay-apart-from-the-three-robes area.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.8: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.9: The Sangha abolishes this may-stay-apart-from-the-three-robes area.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.10: Any monk who approves of abolishing this may-stay-apart-from-the-three-robes area should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.11: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.12: The Sangha has abolished this may-stay-apart-from-the-three-robes area.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.13: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.1: And a monastery zone should be abolished like this.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.2: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.4: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should abolish this monastery zone, defining who belongs to the same community and who should do the observance-day ceremony together.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.6: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.7: The Sangha abolishes this monastery zone, defining who belongs to the same community and who should do the observance-day ceremony together.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.8: Any monk who approves of abolishing this monastery zone, defining who belongs to the same community and who should do the observance-day ceremony together, should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.9: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.10: The Sangha has abolished this monastery zone, defining who belongs to the same community and who should do the observance-day ceremony together.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.11: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’
pli-tv-kd2:12.7.1: “There are monks who live supported by inhabited areas where no monastery zone has been established. In these cases, the zone of the inhabited area defines who belongs to the same community and who should do the observance-day ceremony together.
pli-tv-kd2:12.7.2: If it is an uninhabited area in the wilderness, a distance of 80 meters on all sides defines who belongs to the same community and who should do the observance-day ceremony together.
pli-tv-kd2:12.7.5: or a whole lake cannot be a monastery zone in its own right.
pli-tv-kd2:12.7.6: In a river, in the ocean, and in a lake, the zone that defines who belongs to the same community and who should do the observance-day ceremony together is the distance an average man can splash water in all directions.”
pli-tv-kd2:13.1.1: At one time the monks from the group of six established a monastery zone that overlapped with an existing monastery zone.
pli-tv-kd2:13.1.3: “The establishment of the first zone is a legitimate legal procedure that is irreversible and fit to stand.
pli-tv-kd2:13.1.4: The establishment of the subsequent zone is an illegitimate legal procedure that is reversible and unfit to stand.
pli-tv-kd2:13.1.5: You should not establish a monastery zone that overlaps with an existing monastery zone.
pli-tv-kd2:13.1.6: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:13.2.1: At one time the monks from the group of six established a monastery zone that enclosed one existing monastery zone within it.
pli-tv-kd2:13.2.3: “The establishment of the first zone is a legitimate legal procedure that is irreversible and fit to stand.
pli-tv-kd2:13.2.4: The establishment of the subsequent zone is an illegitimate legal procedure that is reversible and unfit to stand.
pli-tv-kd2:13.2.5: You should not establish a monastery zone that encloses an existing monastery zone.
pli-tv-kd2:13.2.6: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:13.2.7: When you establish a monastery zone, you should leave a gap to any existing monastery zone.”
pli-tv-kd2:14.1.0: 10. Breach of the observance-day ceremony, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:14.1.4: “There are two observance days: the fourteenth and the fifteenth day of the lunar half-month.”
pli-tv-kd2:14.2.2: “How many kinds of observance-day procedure are there?”
pli-tv-kd2:14.2.5: The observance-day procedure that is illegitimate and has an incomplete assembly.
pli-tv-kd2:14.2.6: The observance-day procedure that is illegitimate but has a complete assembly.
pli-tv-kd2:14.2.7: The observance-day procedure that is legitimate but has an incomplete assembly.
pli-tv-kd2:14.2.8: The observance-day procedure that is legitimate and has a complete assembly.
pli-tv-kd2:14.3.3: and third of these should not be done;
pli-tv-kd2:14.3.5: The fourth should be done; I have allowed such a procedure.
pli-tv-kd2:14.3.6: Therefore, monks, you should train like this: ‘We will do observance-day procedures that are legitimate and have a complete assembly.’”
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.0: 11. The recitation of the Monastic Code in brief, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.2: “How many ways are there of reciting the Monastic Code?”
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.4: “There are these five ways of reciting the Monastic Code:
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.5: After reciting the introduction, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.7: After reciting the introduction and the four rules entailing expulsion, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.9: After reciting the introduction, the four rules entailing expulsion, and the thirteen rules entailing suspension, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.11: After reciting the introduction, the four rules entailing expulsion, the thirteen rules entailing suspension, and the two undetermined rules, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-kd2:15.2.2: that the Buddha had allowed the recitation of the Monastic Code in brief,
pli-tv-kd2:15.2.3: some monks recited it in brief all the time.
pli-tv-kd2:15.2.5: “You shouldn’t recite the Monastic Code in brief.
pli-tv-kd2:15.2.6: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:15.3.1: At that time, on the observance day in a certain monastery in the Kosalan country, there was a threat from a primitive tribe.
pli-tv-kd2:15.3.2: The monks were unable to recite the Monastic Code in full.
pli-tv-kd2:15.3.4: “I allow you to recite the Monastic Code in brief when there are threats.”
pli-tv-kd2:15.4.1: The monks from the group of six recited the Monastic Code in brief even when there were no threats.
pli-tv-kd2:15.4.3: “You should not recite the Monastic Code in brief when there are no threats.
pli-tv-kd2:15.4.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:15.4.5: I allow you to recite the Monastic Code in brief when there are any of these threats:
pli-tv-kd2:15.4.7: a threat from kings, bandits, fire, floods, people, spirits, predatory animals, or snakes, or a threat to life, or a threat to the monastic life.”
pli-tv-kd2:15.5.1: On one occasion the monks from the group of six gave a teaching in the midst of the Sangha without being asked.
pli-tv-kd2:15.5.3: “You should not give a teaching in the midst of the Sangha without being asked.
pli-tv-kd2:15.5.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:15.5.5: I allow the most senior monk either to give a teaching himself or to ask someone else.”
pli-tv-kd2:15.6.0: 12. Discussion of questioning on the Monastic Law
pli-tv-kd2:15.6.1: On one occasion the monks from the group of six questioned others on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha without being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.6.3: “You should not question others on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha without being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.6.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:15.6.5: I allow you to question others on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha after being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.6.6: And this is how you are approved:
pli-tv-kd2:15.6.7: either you are approved through yourself or you are approved through someone else.
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.1: And how are you approved through yourself?
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.2: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.4: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, I will question so-and-so on the Monastic Law.’
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.5: In this way you are approved through yourself.
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.6: And how are you approved through someone else?
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.7: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.8: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.9: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, so-and-so will question so-and-so on the Monastic Law.’
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.10: In this way you are approved through someone else.”
pli-tv-kd2:15.8.1: Soon good monks asked questions on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha after being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.8.2: The monks from the group of six became angry and bitter, and they made threats of violence.
pli-tv-kd2:15.8.4: “The monk who has been approved should first survey the gathering and evaluate the individuals, and then ask questions on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha.”
pli-tv-kd2:15.9.0: 13. Discussion of replying to questions on the Monastic Law
pli-tv-kd2:15.9.1: On one occasion the monks from the group of six replied to questions on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha without being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.9.3: “You should not reply to questions on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha without being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.9.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:15.9.5: I allow you to reply to questions on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha after being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.9.6: And this is how you are approved:
pli-tv-kd2:15.9.7: either you are approved through yourself or you are approved through someone else.
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.1: And how are you approved through yourself?
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.2: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.4: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, I will reply when asked by so-and-so on the Monastic Law.’
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.5: In this way you are approved through yourself.
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.6: And how are you approved through someone else?
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.7: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.8: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.9: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, so-and-so will reply when asked by so-and-so on the Monastic Law.’
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.10: In this way you are approved through someone else.”
pli-tv-kd2:15.11.1: Soon good monks replied to questions on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha after being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.11.2: The monks from the group of six became angry and bitter, and they made threats of violence.
pli-tv-kd2:15.11.4: “The monk who has been approved should first survey the gathering and evaluate the individuals, and then reply to questions on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.1.1: At one time the monks from the group of six accused a monk of an offense without first getting his permission to do so.
pli-tv-kd2:16.1.3: “You should not accuse a monk of an offense without first getting his permission.
pli-tv-kd2:16.1.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:16.1.5: You should only accuse someone of an offense after getting their permission:
pli-tv-kd2:16.1.6: ‘I wish to speak to you, Venerable, please give me permission.’”
pli-tv-kd2:16.2.1: Soon, after getting their permission, good monks accused the monks from the group of six of an offense.
pli-tv-kd2:16.2.2: The monks from the group of six became angry and bitter, and they made threats of violence.
pli-tv-kd2:16.2.4: “Even when you have their permission, you should first evaluate the individual and then accuse them of an offense.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.3.1: At this time the monks from the group of six—thinking to act before the good monks asked them for permission, but having no grounds for doing so—got permission from pure monks who had not committed any offenses.
pli-tv-kd2:16.3.3: “When you have no grounds for doing so, you should not get permission from pure monks who haven’t committed any offenses.
pli-tv-kd2:16.3.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:16.3.5: And you should give permission only after evaluating the individual.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.4.0: 15. Objecting to an illegitimate legal procedure, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:16.4.1: On one occasion the monks from the group of six did an illegitimate legal procedure in the midst of the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd2:16.4.3: “You should not do illegitimate legal procedures.
pli-tv-kd2:16.4.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.4.7: “You should object when an illegitimate legal procedure is being done.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.5.1: Soon afterwards good monks objected when the monks from the group of six did an illegitimate procedure.
pli-tv-kd2:16.5.2: The monks from the group of six became angry and bitter, and they made threats of violence.
pli-tv-kd2:16.5.4: “I also allow you to state your view.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.5.6: Once again the monks from the group of six became angry and bitter, making threats of violence.
pli-tv-kd2:16.5.8: “A group of four or five should object, a group of two or three may state their view, and a single person may make a silent determination:
pli-tv-kd2:16.6.1: On one occasion when the monks from the group of six were reciting the Monastic Code in the midst of the Sangha, they deliberately made themselves inaudible.
pli-tv-kd2:16.6.3: “When reciting the Monastic Code, you should not deliberately make yourselves inaudible.
pli-tv-kd2:16.6.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.7.1: At one time Venerable Udāyī was the Sangha’s reciter of the Monastic Code, but he had a hoarse voice.
pli-tv-kd2:16.7.3: that the Buddha had laid down a rule
pli-tv-kd2:16.7.4: that the reciters of the Monastic Code should make themselves heard, and he thought, ‘I have a hoarse voice. What should I do?’
pli-tv-kd2:16.7.6: “The reciter of the Monastic Code should make an effort
pli-tv-kd2:16.7.8: If you make an effort, there’s no offense.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.8.1: On one occasion Devadatta recited the Monastic Code in a gathering that included lay people.
pli-tv-kd2:16.8.3: “You should not recite the Monastic Code in a gathering that includes lay people.
pli-tv-kd2:16.8.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.9.1: On one occasion the monks from the group of six recited the Monastic Code in the midst of the Sangha without being asked.
pli-tv-kd2:16.9.3: “You should not recite the Monastic Code in the midst of the Sangha without first being asked to do so.
pli-tv-kd2:16.9.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:16.9.5: The most senior monk should be in charge of the recitation of the Monastic Code.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.9.6: The first section for recitation on monastics of other religions is finished.
pli-tv-kd2:17.1.0: 16. Requesting the recitation of the Monastic Code, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:17.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Codanāvatthu.
pli-tv-kd2:17.1.2: When he eventually arrived, he stayed there.
pli-tv-kd2:17.1.3: At that time a number of monks were staying in a certain monastery
pli-tv-kd2:17.1.4: where the most senior monk was ignorant and incompetent.
pli-tv-kd2:17.1.5: He did not know about the observance-day ceremony or the observance-day procedure, nor about the Monastic Code or its recitation.
pli-tv-kd2:17.2.2: that the Buddha had laid down a rule
pli-tv-kd2:17.2.3: that the most senior monk should be in charge of the recitation of the Monastic Code,
pli-tv-kd2:17.2.4: and so they wondered what to do.
pli-tv-kd2:17.2.6: “In such a case a competent and capable monk there should be in charge of the recitation of the Monastic Code.”
pli-tv-kd2:17.3.1: On one occasion on the observance day, a number of ignorant and incompetent monks were staying in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd2:17.3.2: They did not know about the observance-day ceremony or the observance-day procedure, nor about the Monastic Code or its recitation.
pli-tv-kd2:17.3.3: They requested the most senior monk
pli-tv-kd2:17.3.7: They made the same request of the second-most
pli-tv-kd2:17.3.16: each monk in turn until they reached the most junior monk.
pli-tv-kd2:17.3.17: And they all gave the same reply.
pli-tv-kd2:17.4.3: “When all the monks in a monastery are ignorant and incompetent,
pli-tv-kd2:17.4.4: and none of them is able to recite the Monastic Code,
pli-tv-kd2:17.5.1: they should straightaway send a monk to a neighboring monastery
pli-tv-kd2:17.5.2: to learn the Monastic Code, either in brief or in full.”
pli-tv-kd2:17.6.4: “The most senior monk should tell a junior monk to go.”
pli-tv-kd2:17.6.5: Although told by the senior monk, the junior monks did not go.
pli-tv-kd2:17.6.7: “If a monk isn’t sick and he’s told by the most senior monk to go, he should go.
pli-tv-kd2:17.6.8: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:18.1.0: 17. The instruction to learn the number of the lunar half-month, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:18.1.1: When he had stayed at Codanāvatthu for as long as he liked, the Buddha returned to Rājagaha.
pli-tv-kd2:18.1.2: Then, while the monks were walking for almsfood, people asked them which half-month it was.
pli-tv-kd2:18.1.7: “These Sakyan monastics don’t even know the number of the lunar half-month. So how could they possibly know anything truly useful?”
pli-tv-kd2:18.1.9: “You should learn the counting of the lunar half-months.”
pli-tv-kd2:18.2.2: “Who should learn the counting of the lunar half-months?”
pli-tv-kd2:18.2.4: “You should all learn the counting of the lunar half-months.”
pli-tv-kd2:18.3.1: On another occasion, while the monks were walking for almsfood, people asked them how many monks there were.
pli-tv-kd2:18.3.6: “These Sakyan monastics don’t even know about one another. So how could they possibly know anything truly useful?”
pli-tv-kd2:18.4.4: “You should count the monks on the observance day, either by name or by distributing tickets.”
pli-tv-kd2:19.1.1: On one occasion, monks walked for almsfood in a faraway village, not knowing that it was the observance day.
pli-tv-kd2:19.1.2: They arrived back while the Monastic Code was being recited or even just after.
pli-tv-kd2:19.1.4: “You should announce, ‘Today is the observance day.’”
pli-tv-kd2:19.1.8: “The most senior monk should make the announcement early in the morning.”
pli-tv-kd2:19.1.9: Soon afterwards a certain senior monk forgot to make the announcement early in the morning.
pli-tv-kd2:19.1.11: “I allow you to make the announcement at the mealtime too.”
pli-tv-kd2:19.1.12: He forgot to make the announcement at the mealtime too.
pli-tv-kd2:19.1.14: “I allow you to make the announcement whenever you remember.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.1.0: 18. The instruction to do the prior duties
pli-tv-kd2:20.1.1: On one occasion in a certain monastery, the observance-day hall was dirty.
pli-tv-kd2:20.1.3: “Why don’t the resident monks sweep the hall?”
pli-tv-kd2:20.2.4: “The most senior monk should tell a junior monk.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.2.5: Although told by the senior monk, the junior monks did not sweep.
pli-tv-kd2:20.2.7: “If a monk isn’t sick and he’s told by the senior monk to sweep, he should sweep.
pli-tv-kd2:20.2.8: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.1: On one occasion no seats were prepared in the observance-day hall.
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.2: The monks sat on the ground. They became dirty, as did their robes.
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.4: “You should prepare seats in the observance-day hall.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.8: “The most senior monk should tell a junior monk.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.9: Although told by the senior monk, the junior monks did not prepare them.
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.11: “If a monk isn’t sick and he’s told by the senior monk to prepare the seats, he should do so.
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.12: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.1: On one occasion there was no lamp in the observance-day hall.
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.2: Because it was dark, the monks stepped on one another and on one another’s robes.
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.4: “You should light a lamp in the observance-day hall.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.8: “The most senior monk should tell a junior monk.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.9: Although told by the senior monk, the junior monks did not light a lamp.
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.11: “If a monk isn’t sick and he’s told by the senior monk to light a lamp, he should do so.
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.12: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.5.1: On one occasion in a certain monastery, the resident monks didn’t set out water for drinking or water for washing.
pli-tv-kd2:20.5.2: Newly arrived monks complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd2:20.5.3: “Why don’t the resident monks set out water for drinking and water for washing?”
pli-tv-kd2:20.5.5: “You should set out water for drinking and water for washing.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.6.4: “The most senior monk should tell a junior monk.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.6.5: Although told by the senior monk, the junior monks did not do it.
pli-tv-kd2:20.6.7: “If a monk isn’t sick and he’s told by the senior monk to set them out, he should do so.
pli-tv-kd2:20.6.8: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.0: 19. Those going to a different region, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.1: On one occasion a number of ignorant and incompetent monks asked permission from their teachers and preceptors to go to a different region.
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.3: “A number of ignorant and incompetent monks might ask their teachers and preceptors for permission to go to a different region.
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.4: The teachers and preceptors should then ask them
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.5: where they’re going and who they’re going with.
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.6: If they’re going with others who are ignorant and incompetent, the teachers and preceptors shouldn’t give them permission.
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.7: If they do, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.8: And if the students go without permission from their teachers and preceptors, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:21.2.1: A number of ignorant and incompetent monks might be staying in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd2:21.2.2: They don’t know about the observance-day ceremony or the observance-day procedure, nor about the Monastic Code or its recitation.
pli-tv-kd2:21.2.3: Then a monk arrives who is learned and a master of the tradition; who is an expert on the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and the key terms; who is knowledgeable and competent, has a sense of conscience, and is afraid of wrongdoing and fond of the training.
pli-tv-kd2:21.2.4: Those monks should treat that learned monk with kindness. They should assist him and support him, and they should attend on him with bath powder, soap, tooth cleaners, and water for rinsing the mouth.
pli-tv-kd2:21.2.5: If they don’t look after him in this way, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd2:22.1.0: 20. Discussion of the passing on of purity
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.1: Then the Buddha addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.2: “Gather, monks, for the Sangha to do the observance-day ceremony.”
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.3: A monk said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.4: “Venerable Sir, there’s a sick monk. He hasn’t come.”
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.5: “A sick monk should pass on his purity.
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.6: And he should do it like this.
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.7: The sick monk should approach a monk, put his upper robe over one shoulder, and squat on his heels. He should then raise his joined palms and say,
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.8: ‘I pass on my purity; please convey my purity; please announce my purity.’
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.9: If he makes this understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then the purity has been passed on.
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.10: If he doesn’t make this understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then the purity hasn’t been passed on.
pli-tv-kd2:22.2.1: If he’s able to do this, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd2:22.2.2: If he’s not, then the sick monk should be brought into the midst of the Sangha together with his bed or bench. They can then do the observance-day ceremony.
pli-tv-kd2:22.2.3: But if the one who is nursing him says,
pli-tv-kd2:22.2.4: ‘If we move him, his illness will get worse, or he’ll die,’ then the sick monk shouldn’t be moved.
pli-tv-kd2:22.2.5: The Sangha should go to where the sick monk is and do the observance-day ceremony there.
pli-tv-kd2:22.2.6: You should not do the observance-day ceremony with an incomplete Sangha.
pli-tv-kd2:22.2.7: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd2:22.4.4: But if, after the purity has been passed on to him, the monk who is conveying the purity departs after reaching the Sangha, then the purity has been brought.
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.5: And if, after the purity has been passed on to him, the monk who is conveying the purity disrobes after reaching the Sangha …
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.6: admits that he’s a hermaphrodite after reaching the Sangha, then the purity has been brought.
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.7: And if, after the purity has been passed on to him, the monk who is conveying the purity reaches the Sangha, but doesn’t announce the purity because he falls asleep or is heedless or gains a meditation attainment, then the purity has been brought.
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.8: There’s no offense for the one who is conveying the purity.
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.9: And if, after the purity has been passed on to him, the monk who is conveying the purity reaches the Sangha, but deliberately doesn’t announce the purity, then the purity has been brought.

pli-tv-kd2:24.1.0: 22. Discussion on being seized by relatives, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:24.1.1: On one occasion on the observance day, a certain monk was seized by his relatives.
pli-tv-kd2:24.1.3: “If a monk is seized by his relatives on the observance day,
pli-tv-kd2:24.1.4: other monks should say to those relatives,
pli-tv-kd2:24.1.5: ‘Please release this monk for a short time so that he can take part in the observance-day ceremony.’
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.1: If they’re able to do this, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.2: If not, they should say to those relatives,
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.3: ‘Please step aside for a moment while this monk passes on his purity.’
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.4: If they’re able to do this, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.5: If not, they should say to those relatives,
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.6: ‘Please take this monk outside the monastery zone for a short time while the Sangha does the observance-day ceremony.’
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.7: If they’re able to do this, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.8: If not, you should not do the observance-day ceremony with an incomplete Sangha.

pli-tv-kd2:25.1.1: Then the Buddha addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd2:25.1.2: “Gather, monks, there’s business for the Sangha.”
pli-tv-kd2:25.1.3: A monk said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd2:25.1.4: “Venerable Sir, there’s a monk called Gagga who is insane. He hasn’t come.”
pli-tv-kd2:25.1.5: “Monks, there are two kinds of insane monks:
pli-tv-kd2:25.1.6: there is the insane monk who sometimes remembers the observance day and sometimes doesn’t, who sometimes remembers the legal procedures of the Sangha and sometimes doesn’t,
pli-tv-kd2:25.1.7: who sometimes goes to the observance-day ceremony and sometimes doesn’t, who sometimes goes to the legal procedures of the Sangha and sometimes doesn’t. Then there’s the insane monk who never remembers any of this.
pli-tv-kd2:25.2.1: For the first one of these, you should make an agreement in regard to insanity.
pli-tv-kd2:25.3.1: And it should be made like this.
pli-tv-kd2:25.3.2: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd2:25.3.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:25.3.5: Sometimes he remembers the observance day and sometimes he doesn’t; sometimes he remembers the legal procedures of the Sangha and sometimes he doesn’t; sometimes he goes to the observance-day ceremony and sometimes he doesn’t; sometimes he goes to the legal procedures of the Sangha and sometimes he doesn’t.
pli-tv-kd2:25.3.6: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should agree on the following in regard to the insanity of the monk Gagga:
pli-tv-kd2:25.3.7: whether or not Gagga remembers either the observance day or the legal procedures of the Sangha, whether or not he comes to either, the Sangha should do the observance-day ceremony, it should do the legal procedures of the Sangha, with or without Gagga.
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.1: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.3: Sometimes he remembers the observance day and sometimes he doesn’t; sometimes he remembers the legal procedures of the Sangha and sometimes he doesn’t; sometimes he goes to the observance-day ceremony and sometimes he doesn’t; sometimes he goes to the legal procedures of the Sangha and sometimes he doesn’t.
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.4: The Sangha agrees on the following in regard to the insanity of the monk Gagga:
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.5: whether or not Gagga remembers either the observance day or the legal procedures of the Sangha, whether or not he comes to either, the Sangha should do the observance-day ceremony, it should do the legal procedures of the Sangha, with or without Gagga.
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.6: Any monk who approves of this agreement—
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.7: whether or not Gagga remembers either the observance day or the legal procedures of the Sangha, whether or not he comes to either, the Sangha should do the observance-day ceremony, it should do the legal procedures of the Sangha, with or without Gagga—should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.8: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.9: The Sangha has agreed on the following in regard to the insanity of the monk Gagga:
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.10: whether or not Gagga remembers either the observance-day ceremony or the legal procedures of the Sangha, whether or not he comes to either, the Sangha should do the observance-day ceremony, it should do the legal procedures of the Sangha, with or without Gagga.
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.11: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
pli-tv-kd2:26.1.0: 24. Various kinds of observance days for the Sangha, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:26.1.1: At one time on the observance day, there were four monks staying in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd2:26.1.3: “The Buddha has laid down a rule
pli-tv-kd2:26.1.4: that the observance-day ceremony should be done. Now there’s four of us. So how should we do the observance-day ceremony?”
pli-tv-kd2:26.1.6: “When there are four of you, you should recite the Monastic Code.”
pli-tv-kd2:26.2.1: At one time on the observance day, there were three monks staying in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd2:26.2.3: “The Buddha has instructed that the Monastic Code should be recited when there are four monks. But there’s only three of us. So how should we do the observance-day ceremony?”
pli-tv-kd2:26.2.5: “When there are three of you, you should do the observance-day ceremony by declaring your purity.
pli-tv-kd2:26.3.1: And you should do it like this.
pli-tv-kd2:26.3.2: A competent and capable monk should inform those monks:
pli-tv-kd2:26.3.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask you to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:26.3.4: Today is the observance day, the fifteenth.
pli-tv-kd2:26.3.5: If it seems appropriate to you, we should do the observance-day ceremony by declaring purity to one another.’
pli-tv-kd2:26.3.6: The most senior monk should put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say to the other monks:
pli-tv-kd2:26.3.9: And he should repeat this two more times.
pli-tv-kd2:26.4.1: Each junior monk should put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say to the other monks:
pli-tv-kd2:26.4.4: And he should repeat this two more times.”
pli-tv-kd2:26.5.1: At one time on the observance day, there were two monks staying in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd2:26.5.3: “The Buddha has instructed that the Monastic Code should be recited when there are four monks and that the observance-day ceremony should be done by declaring purity when there are three.
pli-tv-kd2:26.5.4: But there’s only two of us.
pli-tv-kd2:26.5.5: So how should we do the observance-day ceremony?”
pli-tv-kd2:26.5.7: “When there are two of you, you should do the observance-day ceremony by declaring your purity.
pli-tv-kd2:26.6.1: And you should do it like this.
pli-tv-kd2:26.6.2: The senior monk should put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say to the junior monk:
pli-tv-kd2:26.6.5: And he should repeat this two more times.
pli-tv-kd2:26.7.1: The junior monk should put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say to the senior monk:
pli-tv-kd2:26.7.4: And he should repeat this two more times.”
pli-tv-kd2:26.8.1: At one time on the observance day, a monk was staying in a certain monastery by himself.
pli-tv-kd2:26.8.3: “The Buddha has instructed that the Monastic Code should be recited when there are four monks and that the observance-day ceremony should be done by declaring purity when there are two or three.
pli-tv-kd2:26.8.5: So how should I do the observance-day ceremony?”
pli-tv-kd2:26.9.1: “On the observance day, a monk might be staying by himself in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd2:26.9.2: He should sweep the place where the monks normally go: whether the assembly hall, under a roof-cover, or at the foot of a tree. He should set out water for drinking and water for washing. He should prepare a seat, light a lamp, and sit down.
pli-tv-kd2:26.9.3: If other monks arrive, he should do the observance-day ceremony with them.
pli-tv-kd2:26.9.4: If not, he should determine: ‘Today is my observance day.’
pli-tv-kd2:26.9.5: If he doesn’t make a determination, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:26.10.1: Wherever four monks are staying together, three shouldn’t recite the Monastic Code, while the purity of the fourth is brought.
pli-tv-kd2:26.10.2: If you do recite the Monastic Code, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:26.10.3: Wherever three monks are staying together, two shouldn’t do the observance-day ceremony by declaring purity, while the purity of the third is brought.
pli-tv-kd2:26.10.4: If you do declare purity, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:26.10.5: Wherever two monks are staying together, one shouldn’t make a determination, while the purity of the other is brought.
pli-tv-kd2:26.10.6: If you do make a determination, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:27.1.0: 25. The process for making amends for an offense
pli-tv-kd2:27.1.1: On one occasion on the observance day, a certain monk committed an offense.
pli-tv-kd2:27.1.3: “The Buddha has laid down a rule
pli-tv-kd2:27.1.4: that one shouldn’t do the observance-day ceremony if one has an offense.
pli-tv-kd2:27.1.8: “On the observance day, a monk may have committed an offense.
pli-tv-kd2:27.1.9: He should approach a monk, put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say,
pli-tv-kd2:27.1.10: ‘I’ve committed such-and-such an offense. I confess it.’
